title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 6soil moisture from SAR
text:
Introduction (1)
SAR is sensitive to the dielectric and geometric properties of a target. The intensity and scattering of SAR responses are impacted by the volume of water in the soil, the surface roughness, and the vegetation cover. For bare soil conditions, backscatter intensity is linearly related to volumetric soil moisture. The use of bare soil models to estimate soil moisture under vegetated conditions yields high soil moisture uncertainties.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 6soil moisture from SAR
text:
Introduction (2)
Several descriptors such as the Radar Vegetation Index (RVI) for dual-pol, Dual-Pol SAR Vegetation Index (DPSVI), and Dual-pol Radar Vegetation Index (DpRVI) have been developed for crop growth monitoring and biophysical parameter retrieval. These descriptors do not exploit the complete polarimetric information in characterizing a target. Bhogapurapu et al.Â (2022) introduced a novel vegetation descriptor that exploits the available polarimetric information in dualpol GRD SAR data (i.e purity and intensity).

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 7 -Data Fusion
text:
Preparing Sentinel-1 Analysis Ready Data in GEE
GEE provides global-scale and analysis-ready earth observation data and the cloud computing infrastructure required for their analysis. For SAR imagery, however, Analysis Ready Data (ARD) is a concept that can vary by application.
While radiometric terrain normalization is a recommended preprocessing step for most applications, may not be conducted due to the absence of reliable DSMs. The Sentinel-1 SAR data ingested in GEE is limited to thermal noise removals, data calibration, multi-looking, and range-doppler terrain correction.
For a range of applications, it is advantageous to do additional preprocessing steps, such as speckle filtering and radiometric terrain normalization. However, expert knowledge is needed to implement the additional preprocessing steps.
Thus, in order to support additional Sentinel-1 SAR data preprocessing in GEE, Adugna Mellisa et al.Â (2021) proposed a comprehensive framework for preparing Sentinel-1 SAR backscatter ARD in GEE suitable for a wide range of applications.


The Mullisa workflow
The implemented framework to get Sentinel-1 ARD includes additional border noise removal, speckle filtering, and radiometric terrain normalization. All the additional preprocessing can be adjusted by the user depending on their specific needs.





Hands-on exercise
The framework is implemented in both GEE Javascript and the Python application programming interface (API).
To use the framework in GEE code editor, go to this repository and copy the contents of the s1_ard.js script to your own repository. The path to the preprocessing functions is a public so you donâ€™t need to copy them.
When using the Python API, the user should adjust the script path and GEE id to their own path and id before processing.
Click here to try it.






NoteAdditional resources






Mullisaâ€™s paper


Mullisaâ€™s repository

Preparing Sentinel-1 Analysis Ready Data in GEE
GEE provides global-scale and analysis-ready earth observation data and the cloud computing infrastructure required for their analysis. For SAR imagery, however, Analysis Ready Data (ARD) is a concept that can vary by application.
While radiometric terrain normalization is a recommended preprocessing step for most applications, may not be conducted due to the absence of reliable DSMs. The Sentinel-1 SAR data ingested in GEE is limited to thermal noise removals, data calibration, multi-looking, and range-doppler terrain correction.
For a range of applications, it is advantageous to do additional preprocessing steps, such as speckle filtering and radiometric terrain normalization. However, expert knowledge is needed to implement the additional preprocessing steps.
Thus, in order to support additional Sentinel-1 SAR data preprocessing in GEE, Adugna Mellisa et al.Â (2021) proposed a comprehensive framework for preparing Sentinel-1 SAR backscatter ARD in GEE suitable for a wide range of applications.


The Mullisa workflow

title: 2027449 - PERCEPCION REMOTA AVANZADA
text:
ğŸ“‘ Course Brief
Focus: the focus of this course is to gain knowledge for developing novel remote sensing analysis workflows.
How: reading, learning by doing and writing


ğŸ¯ Learning Objectives

Appraise the process of image analysis and its relation to research.
Dive deep into the physical principles of multispectral remote sensing.
Distinguish the main principles of deep learning for Earth Observation data.
Apply AI techniques to obtain thematic information from Earth Observation data.

 2025

For a range of applications, it is advantageous to do additional preprocessing steps, such as speckle filtering and radiometric terrain normalization. However, expert knowledge is needed to implement the additional preprocessing steps.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 03 - Practical exercise
text:
Preparing Sentinel-1 Analysis Ready Data in GEE
GEE provides global-scale and analysis-ready earth observation data and the cloud computing infrastructure required for their analysis. For SAR imagery, however, Analysis Ready Data (ARD) is a concept that can vary by application.
While radiometric terrain normalization is a recommended preprocessing step for most applications, may not be conducted due to the absence of reliable DSMs. The Sentinel-1 SAR data ingested in GEE is limited to thermal noise removals, data calibration, multi-looking, and range-doppler terrain correction.
For a range of applications, it is advantageous to do additional preprocessing steps, such as speckle filtering and radiometric terrain normalization. However, expert knowledge is needed to implement the additional preprocessing steps.
Thus, in order to support additional Sentinel-1 SAR data preprocessing in GEE, Adugna Mellisa et al.Â (2021) proposed a comprehensive framework for preparing Sentinel-1 SAR backscatter ARD in GEE suitable for a wide range of applications.


The Mullisa workflow
The implemented framework to get Sentinel-1 ARD includes additional border noise removal, speckle filtering, and radiometric terrain normalization. All the additional preprocessing can be adjusted by the user depending on their specific needs.





Hands-on exercise
The framework is implemented in both GEE Javascript and the Python application programming interface (API).
To use the framework in GEE code editor, go to this repository and copy the contents of the s1_ard.js script to your own repository. The path to the preprocessing functions is a public so you donâ€™t need to copy them.
When using the Python API, the user should adjust the script path and GEE id to their own path and id before processing.
Click here to try it.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 6soil moisture from SAR
text:
Introduction (1)
SAR is sensitive to the dielectric and geometric properties of a target. The intensity and scattering of SAR responses are impacted by the volume of water in the soil, the surface roughness, and the vegetation cover. For bare soil conditions, backscatter intensity is linearly related to volumetric soil moisture. The use of bare soil models to estimate soil moisture under vegetated conditions yields high soil moisture uncertainties.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 6soil moisture from SAR
text:
Introduction (2)
Several descriptors such as the Radar Vegetation Index (RVI) for dual-pol, Dual-Pol SAR Vegetation Index (DPSVI), and Dual-pol Radar Vegetation Index (DpRVI) have been developed for crop growth monitoring and biophysical parameter retrieval. These descriptors do not exploit the complete polarimetric information in characterizing a target. Bhogapurapu et al.Â (2022) introduced a novel vegetation descriptor that exploits the available polarimetric information in dualpol GRD SAR data (i.e purity and intensity).
